title: Gay Rites Are Civil Rites
summary:
Key ideas:
- Cultural evolution and shared religion can bind people together and build social trust, making a city into a community.
- American civil religion is a form of symbiosis between society and ideology.
- The American civil religion has lost its sacredness and can no longer answer questions of group identity.
- The San Francisco Gay Pride Parade can be seen as a sublimated Fourth of July Parade, representing a replacement of the American civil religion by social justice.
- Religion adapts to the demands placed on it
- Christianity adopted all the best values (e.g., chastity, family, tradition, patriotism) to be relevant
- The celebration of gay pride is expressing itself in very predictable ways after only fifty years
- Socially useful values change, and religion needs to evolve too
- Social justice will recapitulate the history of other civil religions in fast-forward

Key learnings:
- Religion, on a basic level, answers questions of group identity and why a social system is legitimate.
- The American civil religion has historically been a form of patriotism uniting the country, but it has lost its sacredness and ability to answer the questions of group identity.
- Social justice can be seen as a form of civil religion, with its own answers to the questions of group identity and legitimacy.
- Christianity became Christianity because it adapted, not because of its original doctrine and ideas
- Civil religions adapt and change to stay culturally relevant
- It took only fifty years for the celebration of gay pride to become mainstream, indicating the speed of cultural evolution

Key questions:
- What are the elements of a successful civil religion? How can it answer the questions of group identity and social system legitimacy?
- Why has the American civil religion lost its sacredness? Can it be revitalized?
- In what other ways can social justice be seen as a form of civil religion? What are some potential benefits and drawbacks of this perspective?
- Will social justice look like a mainstream religion in a hundred years, as civil religion adapts?
- How will religion evolve to incorporate changing socially useful values (e.g., chastity or martial valor)?
